p.s: inIn your last e-mail you asked me if I was able to help you out with your presentation about unusual school projects and I found something that might help you: I read an article about chess as a school subject.
It was written by a German journalist called Joachim GÃ¶rres and published on the 30th June 2020 in the newspaper TAZ which is a trustworthy daily journal in Germany.
The idea of this chess project is taht students either have chess as an elective or even as a compulsory class.
Once a week, they have chess class and their teachers who have undergone further trainings to teach chess hold these classes and the students play and learn strategies.
At the end of the year, they can attend a tournament to show what they have learned.
The project is organised by Germany's national chess association.
They claim that the chess class improves the students' general academic performance as well as their ability of logical and strategic thinking.
Moreover, chess helps the students to a better concentration and the teachers also report better communication and behaviour in their classes.
The project also teaches the participants competences like dealing with being defeated, weighung up consequences to one's actions and following rules.
I think this project sounds great because the students will learn skills for life - I hope you think so too and find this information helpful for your presentation.
